Review Research progress of precise structural regulation of single atom catalyst for accelerating electrocatalytic oxygen reduction reaction Minmin Wang Hui Zhang Yunqi Liu Yuan Pan ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum (East China), Qingdao 266580, Shandong, China State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing China University of Petroleum (East China) Qingdao 266580 Shandong China State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum (East China), Qingdao 266580, Shandong, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract In this work, the research progress, structural precision regulation methods for improving the activity and stability, in-situ characterization technologies, challenges and future design directions of SACs for ORR are discussed. The development and utilization of renewable clean energy can effectively solve the two major problems of energy and environment. As an efficient power generation device that converts hydrogen energy into electric energy, fuel cell has attracted more and more attention. For fuel cells, the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) at the cathode is the core reaction, and the design and development of high-performance ORR catalysts remain quite challenging. Since the microenvironment of the active center of single atom catalysts (SACs) has an important influence on its catalytic performance, it has been a research focus to improve the ORR activity and stability of electrocatalysts by adjusting the structure of the active center through reasonable structural regulation methods. In this review, we reviewed the preparation and structure–activity relationship of SACs for ORR. Then, the structural precision regulation methods for improving the activity and stability of ORR electrocatalysts are discussed. And the advanced in-situ characterization techniques for revealing the changes of active sites in the electrocatalytic ORR process are summarized. Finally, the challenges and future design directions of SACs for ORR are discussed. This work will provide important reference value for the design and synthesis of SACs with high activity and stability for ORR. Keywords Electrocatalyst Oxygen reduction reaction Structure regulation Single atom catalysts In-situ characterization technique 1 Introduction Energy shortage and environmental pollution are the major problems that mankind urgently needs to solve. The development and utilization of renewable clean energy become the most effective way to solve the contradiction between energy and environment. Proton exchange membrane fuel cell (PEMFC) is an efficient power generation device that converts hydrogen energy into electric energy [1–3]. It has the advantages of fast start-up at room temperature, high energy conversion, good stability, and pollution-free. PEMFC is considered one of the most promising energy conversion and storage technologies in the field of new energy, which can effectively replace the traditional fossil energy. However, slow ORR dynamics leads to the low conversion efficiency of PEMFC [4–8]. Pt is currently the most efficient catalyst in fuel cells, but its high price and insufficient production make fuel cells too expensive and impossible to achieve large-scale industrial applications [9–11]. In addition, Pt also has problems of easy dissolution, agglomeration, and poisoning in practical application, which greatly restricts the development of PEMFC. Therefore, it is of great significance to develop low-load noble metal or non-noble metal ORR catalyst. In recent years, the rapid development of single atom catalysts (SACs) provides a research direction for the development of high-performance ORR catalysts [12–24]. Compared with bulk catalysts and nanocatalysts, SACs have the highest atomic utilization and can greatly reduce the amount of metal [25]. Meanwhile, SACs have clear atomic configuration, which provides an ideal model for explaining the origin of high catalytic activity. In addition, advanced characterization techniques and density functional theory (DFT) calculations provide important means for understanding the coordination structure and reaction mechanism of SACs, making it possible to improve the activity and stability of electrocatalytic SACs for ORR by precise structural regulation. In this review, we mainly focus on SACs for electrocatalytic ORR and their precise structural regulation methods. Firstly, the applications of noble metals (Pt, Ru, etc.), non-noble metals (Fe, Co, Cu, etc.), and non-metal (Se) SACs in electrocatalytic ORR are reviewed. Then, we focus on several structural precision regulation methods for improving the activity and stability of SACs for ORR. In addition, we introduce in-situ characterization techniques for revealing the structural evolution of active sites of SACs during ORR process. Finally, we summarize the challenges in the development of SACs for electrocatalytic ORR, and look into the future design direction of SACs (Fig. 1 ). 2 Single atom catalysts for ORR The high cost of ORR catalysts has seriously hindered the large-scale production of PEMFCs. The key to the development of PEMFCs is to develop non-noble metal catalysts or to improve the atomic efficiency of noble metals. With maximum atomic efficiency and well-defined active sites, SACs have been proven to have excellent electrocatalytic ORR performance (Fig. 2 ) [26–45]. The development of SACs with high ORR activity and stability may be an important way to solve the cost problem of PEMFCs. The application of SACs in electrochemical ORR in recent years will be briefly introduced below. 2.1 Noble metal SACs At present, fuel cells still use noble metals (such as Pt) as catalysts, but the problem of scarcity and the high price of noble metals cannot be solved. Reducing the use of noble metals and developing noble metal SACs are important research directions to promote the large-scale development of fuel cells. Using ZIF-8 as the precursor, Liu et al. [46] synthesized carbon-supported N-coordinated noble metal SACs (Ir, Rh, Pt, Pd SACs). In acidic electrolytes, the ORR activities of Ir1-N/C and Rh1-N/C are significantly higher than those of nanoparticle catalysts (Ir/C and Rh/C). In contrast, the activities of Pd1-N/C and Pt1-N/C were significantly lower than those of Pd/C and Pt/C. According to DFT calculations, the ORR activity of noble metal SACs depended on the matching of OH* adsorption on the noble metal and the electronegativity of coordinating anion. 2.1.1 Pt SACs Pt-based catalysts are the best-performing ORR catalysts reported so far [47–51]. To reduce the cost, many Pt alloys and core-shell Pt catalysts have been reported in recent years to improve the utilization of Pt in ORR. The low-coordination unsaturated coordination environment of SACs and the strong interaction between single atoms (SAs) and supports play an important role in improving catalytic activity and stability. Pt SACs have been reported to have high H2O2 selectivity, so it remains a challenge to design Pt SACs that can reduce O2 to H2O. Yin et al. [52] reported a green method for the preparation of Pt SACs (Pt1-meso-SC) by underpotential deposition of Cu atoms on S-doped carbon structures followed by galvanic displacement reaction (Fig. 3 d). Benefited from the unique isolated adsorption active sites, the Pt1-meso-S-C catalyst exhibited high selectivity in the electrochemical reduction of O2 to H2O2 without promoting the continuous decomposition of H2O2 (Fig. 3e and f), the exact amount of H2O2 produced by Pt1-meso-S-C catalyst at 0.097 V for 120 min was 28.25 mM, which was very different from the 4e− ORR commonly seen on Pt nanoparticles. This work demonstrated the extremely high selectivity of Pt SACs for ORR to H2O2 and demonstrated that the reaction mechanism can be tuned by adjusting the dispersion of Pt-based catalysts. Lai et al. [53] deposited Pt SAs on the surface, subsurface, and carbon frameworks of Co particles (Fig. 3a). It is found that designing additional Pt SAs (Ptsubsurf) on the subsurface could tune the local environment of Pt1 and significantly improve the catalytic efficiency of surface Pt SAs for ORR. The Pt1@Co/NC catalyst exhibited good electrocatalytic ORR performance in 0.1 M HClO4, and its half-wave potential (E 1/2) was 43 mV higher than that of Pt/C (Fig. 3b). The mass activity (MA) at 0.9 V (all potentials in this paper are reported with respect to reversible hydrogen electrode unless otherwise noted) was 4.2 mA μgPt −1, which was 28 times higher than that of Pt/C (Fig. 3c). After 30,000 CV cycles, its E1/2 decayed only 11 mV, showing good stability. Song et al. [54] prepared Pt SACs on MOF-derived N-doped carbon (MOF-NC) supports by atomic deposition. Pt SACs exhibited high electrocatalytic ORR activity and stability with an E 1/2 of 0.875 V, and the MA at 0.9 V was 1.17 A mgPt −1. DFT calculations showed that Pt SAs were more inclined to be anchored by N-doped pyridine carbon sites (Pt-N1-C2). Li et al. [55] proposed a photochemical solid-phase reduction method to prepare Pt SACs (Pt1/NPC) with well-defined Pt-N4 sites (3.8 wt%). The Pt1/NPC catalyst exhibited excellent ORR activity (E 1/2 = 0.887 V) and stability. After 10,000 CV cycles, E 1/2 lost only 7 mV. The above work proves that reasonable regulation of Pt coordination environment can promote the 4e− ORR process. 2.1.2 Ru SACs Cui et al. [56] developed a sol–gel pore-sealing strategy to prepare Ru-SAs@N-ACSs by anchoring Ru-N4 active sites at the pore edge. The Ru-SAs@N-ACSs exhibited good ORR activity (E 1/2 = 0.87 V), extremely high stability, and excellent methanol tolerance under alkaline conditions (Fig. 3g). DFT calculations showed that OH* was immobilized on Ru-N4 at the edge to form a stable Ru-N4_OH configuration at a broad potential of 0–1.1 V, which was considered the active site in the ORR process (Fig. 3h). The Ru-N4_OH located at the edge had lower binding energy of ORR intermediates, so Ru-SAs@N-ACSs exhibited excellent ORR catalytic activity. Zhang et al. [30] synthesized atomically dispersed Ru sites (Ru-N/G) on N-doped graphene. Atomically dispersed Ru-N4 active sites were revealed by aberration corrected high-angle annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscopy (AC-HAADF-STEM), X-ray absorption near-edge structures (XANES) spectroscopy, and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectroscopy. Ru-N/G-750 catalyst showed good onset potential (E onset = 0.89 V), durability, methanol resistance, and anti-CO poisoning performance. Peng et al. [57], for the first time, reported Ru SAs anchored on Ti3C2T x MXene nanosheets as a trifunctional electrocatalyst (Ru-SA/Ti3C2T x ). For ORR, the E 1/2 of Ru-SA/Ti3C2T x catalyst under acidic conditions was 0.8 V, and the MA was 1.77 A mgRu −1. In addition, the catalyst exhibited extremely high PEMFC activity up to 941 mW cm−2. DFT calculations showed that the Ru-O2 active sites could effectively optimize the adsorption of reactants or intermediates, lowering the potential barrier of the decision step. 2.1.3 Ir SACs To determine an ideal ORR metal center, the adsorption free energy (ΔG OH*) of OH* on a series of M-N-C SACs was calculated. Among the various catalysts, Ir-N-C SACs show ΔG OH* closest to the apex of the volcano diagram [58]. Furthermore, previous studies have shown that iridium porphyrins exhibit the highest ORR activity among porphyrin metals in acidic electrolytes [59]. Given this, researchers synthesized Ir SACs for ORR. Xiao et al. [35] first synthesized homogeneous iridium porphyrin-like Ir-N-C SACs (Ir-SAC) for ORR under acidic conditions (Fig. 3i). AC-HAADF-STEM and X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) revealed the existence of a large number of Ir-N4 coordinated activity sites (Fig. 3j). The Ir-SAC exhibited high ORR catalytic performance with an E onset of 0.97 V, an E 1/2 of 0.864 V, and a MA of 12.2 A mgIr −1. Furthermore, Ir-SAC showed an ultra-high turnover frequency (TOF) of 24.3 e−1site−1s−1 at 0.85 V, surpassing Pt/C. The experimental results and DFT calculations confirmed that the high activity of Ir-SAC was due to the unique electronic structure of the Ir active center of Ir-N4 configuration, which enables it to have the best adsorption energy to the intermediates (Fig. 3k). 2.1.4 Pd SACs Kim et al. [36] prepared Pd SACs (C@C3N4-Pd1) utilizing the abundant N-anchoring sites in the C@C3N4 support. AC-HAADF-STEM and XAS characterizations proved that Pd existed in the form of SAs in the C@C3N4-0.5%Pd catalyst. The C@C3N4-0.5%Pd catalyst exhibited high MA (8.5 A mgPd −1 at 0.2 V) and 94% selectivity for H2O2 (Fig. 3l and m). DFT calculations indicated that the Pd SAs on C@C3N4 had weaker binding energy to O2, resulting in enhanced activity. Moreover, the generation path of H2O2 on C@C3N4-Pd1 was always downward, which improved the selectivity of H2O2. It can be seen from the above that Pt SACs show excellent performance under acidic/alkaline conditions. In addition, the electrocatalytic ORR performance of Ru SACs, Ir SACs, and Pd SACs is also comparable to Pt/C. The above examples show that the monatomization of noble metals can solve the problems of high cost and low reserve of noble metals to a certain extent on the premise of maintaining ideal ORR performance. 2.2 Non-noble metal SACs Although noble metals are considered to be efficient electrocatalysts for ORR, they are limited to large-scale commercial application in the long run due to their high price, low reserves, and poor stability in acidic conditions. Therefore, non-noble metal-based catalysts have become a hot research topic in this field in recent years. Up to fourteen kinds of non-noble metal-based SACs have been reported for electrocatalysis of ORR, among which transition metal-based SACs are the most widely studied [6,16,60–78]. 2.2.1 Mn SACs Compared with other transition metals with high intrinsic activity such as Fe and Co, Mn is generally considered to be less active for ORR. Although manganese oxides have been reported as ORR catalysts, most of their properties are still unsatisfactory. Studies have shown that Mn atoms can be designed as ideal electrocatalytic ORR active sites as long as the coordination environment of Mn is changed and the energy level of the d electrons of Mn is adjusted to a reasonable state. Yan et al. [79] synthesized pyrrole-type MnN4 site catalysts (PT MnN4) on ultrathin carbon nanosheets for the first time using a simple biomimetic enzyme-induced strategy (Fig. 4 a). PT MnN4 SACs had excellent ORR with an E onset of 0.95 V and an E 1/2 of 0.88 V in alkaline medium (Fig. 4b and c). The PT MnN4 SACs also achieved high intrinsic catalytic activity and high selectivity over the whole pH range. The Zn-air battery assembled with PT Mn4 SACs as cathode exhibited high peak power density (175 mW cm−2) and long-term stability up to 150 h. Li et al. [34] prepared an atomically dispersed Mn-N-C catalyst with high Mn-N4 active site density by a two-step doping and adsorption method. In acidic medium, the E 1/2 of Mn-N-C catalyst was 0.80 V. The robust MnN4 sites and the corrosion resistance of the adjacent carbon can significantly enhance the stability of the catalyst, with an E 1/2 loss of only 17 mV after 30000 CV cycles. After 100 h of long-term stability testing, the 20Mn-NC-second catalyst maintained 88% of the initial current density with an E 1/2 loss of 29 mV. DFT calculations confirmed that the MnN4C12 site had suitable binding energy with intermediates and could break the O–O bond for complete 4e− reduction. The above proved that Mn-N4 is a highly effective active site for improving ORR performance. 2.2.2 Fe SACs Among the reported non-noble metal catalysts, the application of Fe-NC catalysts in ORR has been extensively studied [72,80–83], especially the Fe-N4 active group has the highest ORR catalytic activity reported so far. At present, Fe SACs are the most popular non-noble metal catalyst in ORR research. However, it is still a challenging problem to identify the coordination environment and further optimize the catalytic activity of Fe-NC catalyst. Using a self-sacrificial strategy, Li et al. [84] successfully prepared unique asymmetric N, S-coordinated and axial hydroxyl (OH)-coordinated Fe SAs intercalated into porous carbon nanospheres (Fe-N3S1OH) (Fig. 4d and e). The fifth coordination Fe-N3S1OH catalyst exhibited excellent ORR electrocatalytic activity, methanol tolerance, and durability. The peak power densities of Fe-N3S1OH-based H2-O2 fuel cell and air battery were 512 and 203 mW cm−2, respectively. DFT calculations confirmed that the axial OH in Fe N3S1OH could optimize the 3d orbital of the Fe center and enhanced the adsorption and activation of O2 on the Fe site, thereby lowering the ORR barrier and accelerating the ORR kinetics (Fig. 4f). This work reveals the advantages and great potential of fifth coordination SACs for energy conversion and storage. Li et al. [85] prepared Fe SACs on N-doped carbon nanosheets. FeNCS catalysts with M@N3C1 active sites exhibited excellent ORR performance in both acidic and basic conditions. DFT calculations showed that C atoms at M@N3C1 can provide additional co-adsorption sites for oxygen activation due to the interaction between d/p orbitals of M/C atoms, promoting the double site catalysis. This work provides new opportunities to explore active sites with highly active structures. Deng et al. [86] reported C-FeHZ8@g-C3N4-950 catalyst, which exhibited excellent ORR performance. The C-FeHZ8@g-C3N4-950-based PEMFC exhibited ultra-high performance with a high current density (400 mA cm−2 at 0.7 V, 133 mA cm−2 at 0.8 V), and a maximum power density of 628 mW cm−2. Jiang et al. [87] synthesized a Fe-CNT catalyst with Fe-C-O coordination, which showed high 2e− activity and selectivity. With a high E onset of 0.822 V (at 0.1 mA cm−2) for H2O2 generation in 0.1 M KOH, the selectivity was over 95% in alkaline and neutral electrolytes. DFT calculation showed that C sites in Fe-C-O structure were the active sites of selective reduction of O2 to H2O2. In addition, the effectiveness of Fe-CNT catalyst in water disinfection was proved. Shi et al. [88] designed a novel gas doping method to synthesize ZIF-8-derived N and Fe atoms co-doped porous carbon nanocubes (PCN-A@Fe SA) (Fig. 4g). PCN-A@Fe SA exhibited excellent ORR activity in both alkaline and acidic media, with an E 1/2 of 0.905 V in alkaline and 0.79 V in acidic conditions (Fig. 4h and i). The discharge power density of PCN-A@Fe SA-based Zn-air battery reached 185 mW·cm−2. The PEMFC achieved a high power density of 514 mW cm−2. DFT calculations further indicated that Fe2+N4 was the main active center, which was conducive to the adsorption of oxygen and the desorption of OH*, thus improving the ORR performance. The above examples demonstrate that Fe SACs can achieve an efficient 4e− ORR process. The key reason why the current Fe-N-C materials cannot replace Pt/C in PEMFC is the poor stability of Fe-based catalysts in acidic media. On the one hand, due to the protonation of N with lone pair electrons in Fe-N by H+ attack, the Fe-N coordination bond is destroyed, resulting in the loss of Fe, and the effective active sites of the catalyst are significantly reduced, resulting in the deterioration of the catalyst performance. On the other hand, Fe-N-C catalysts undergo a Fenton reaction, and the low-valence Fe2+ in the catalyst accelerates the decomposition of H2O2 to form highly active OH radicals, destroying the structure of the catalyst, resulting in a rapid decline in stability. Improving the stability of Fe-based ORR catalysts under acidic conditions is the biggest challenge at present, which is also the direction of the efforts of the majority of scientific researchers. 2.2.3 Co SACs Although Fe-NC catalysts have excellent electrocatalytic activity, the Fenton reaction makes it difficult to achieve high stability. To reduce the formation of OH radicals in the Fenton reaction and improve the catalyst stability, it is necessary to develop non-Fe-based non-noble metal ORR cathode catalysts, among which Co-based catalysts have attracted extensive attention from researchers [89–93]. Guo et al. [96] synthesized B-doped Co-N-C SACs (Co-N,B-CSs) with enhanced bifunctional ORR and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) activities and stability. DFT calculations confirmed that the introduction of B atoms can provide electron-deficient sites, which in turn can activate electron transfer around the Co-N-C site and strengthen the interaction with oxygen-containing species, thereby accelerating the 4e− ORR process. Wang et al. [97] prepared high-performance Co SACs with CoN4 coordination (20Co-NC-1100). 20Co-NC-1100 catalyst showed excellent electrocatalytic activity under acidic conditions, with an E 1/2 of 0.8 V and significantly improved stability. The initial activity remained 83% after 100 h at a relatively high potential of 0.7 V. Fuel cell testing confirmed that the high activity and stability of 20Co-NC-1100 catalyst are expected to be applied in PEMFC in the future. He et al. [94] developed an innovative surfactant (F127 block copolymer)-assisted MOF method to prepare a core–shell structured Co-N-C catalyst (Co-N-C@F127). In acidic electrolyte, the Co-N-C@F127 catalyst exhibited ultra-high ORR activity with an E 1/2 of 0.84 V. It also showed excellent stability, with a loss of only 40 mV for E 1/2 after 30,000 CV cycles (Fig. 4j) and an initial activity of 94.5% after 100 h of testing at 0.7 V (Fig. 4k). DFT calculations showed that Co-N-C@F127 catalyst contained a large number of CoN2+2 sites, which thermodynamically favored the 4e− ORR pathway. Co SACs with high H2O2 activity and selectivity can be synthesized by designing the structure of catalysts reasonably, for example, Li et al. [98] synthesized a co-modified carbon-based catalyst of Co-N X -C and oxygen functional groups (Co-POC-O) by using a synergistic strategy. Co-POC-O catalyst had high ORR activity and H2O2 selectivity, with the reaction activity reaching 0.79 V at 1 mA cm−2 and the selectivity over 80%. Mechanism studies had shown that Co-N X -C site was the active site of ORR, and oxygen functional groups could improve the selectivity of 2e− ORR. This work provides research ideas for the design of high-performance H2O2 electrocatalysts. 2.2.4 Ni SACs Cai et al. [99] obtained NiN4-C catalysts by supporting Ni-N4 sites on a unique three-dimensional (3D) hierarchical structure. DFT calculations and experimental results illustrated that the high 4e− ORR activity of NiN4-C catalyst was due to its abundant and uniformly distributed Ni-N4 active sites, unique 3D hierarchical structure, and high degree of graphitization. Qiu et al. [100] doped high-density Ni SAs/clusters (23 wt%) on 3D nanoporous N-doped graphene. Doping N significantly improved the doping amount and stability of Ni, and co-doping of Ni and N significantly improved the catalytic activity of OER and ORR in alkaline condition. 3D co-doped graphene-based all-solid Zn-air battery could work stably for a long time. DFT calculation results showed that the synergistic effect of N and Ni doping promotes ORR. 2.2.5 Cu SACs Copper metalloenzymes can efficiently catalyze ORR at low overpotentials, in which the Cu–N center can serve as the active site, and the surrounding ligands can stabilize the structure of the active site. On this basis, researchers have synthesized a variety of Cu–N complexes with similar structures to simulate the coordination environment of copper metalloenzymes and improve the electrocatalytic ORR performance of Cu-based catalysts [65,101,102]. Sun et al. [103] reported Cu SACs with different Cu1+/Cu2+ ratios (Cu-SA/NC(meso)) as an efficient ORR electrocatalyst. The Cu1+-SA/NC(meso)-7 catalyst exhibited excellent ORR activity in alkaline medium with an E 1/2 of 0.898 V, with high durability and enhanced methanol resistance. In addition, the rechargeable Zn-air battery based on Cu1+-SA/NC(meso)-7 electrode exhibited excellent performance and high power density. Experiments and DFT calculations showed that the excellent ORR activity of the Cu1+-SA/NC(meso)-7 catalyst mainly depended on the highly dispersed Cu1+ sites, while the enhanced mesoporous structure improves the accessibility of the active sites inside the Cu1+. Li et al. [95] reported Cu SACs anchored to an ultrathin 2D N-doped carbon substrate (Cu-N-C). By introducing additional N species during the bottom-up synthesis, Cu atoms can be safely trapped and protected, resulting in a Cu content of up to 20.9 wt% in Cu-N-C (Fig. 4l). Cu-N-C exhibited excellent electrocatalytic ORR activity, MA was 54 times higher than that of metallic Cu nanoparticles at 0.85 V. The kinetic current of Cu-N-C at 0.85 V was 3.2 times that of Pt/C (Fig. 4m). DFT results showed that Cu SAs had good adsorption energy for O2 and OOH and improved the stretching of O = O bonds (Fig. 4n), thereby accelerating the ORR process. The above results indicate that high performance Cu SACs still need to be further explored, and the synthesis of Cu SACs with high active site density by adjusting the coordination environment of Cu center or developing efficient preparation methods is the direction of future efforts. These results indicate that high-performance Cu SACs still need to be explored. The catalytic performance of Cu SACs may be improved by adjusting the coordination environment of Cu center or increasing the density of active site. 2.2.6 Zn SACs Atomically dispersed Zn-N-C materials are promising ORR catalysts. However, the d orbital (3d 104s 2) of the Zn element is filled, so high-valence oxide ions cannot be formed, and the Zn precursor is highly volatile during the high-temperature annealing process, so the preparation of highly Zn-supported Zn-NC catalysts is still a daunting challenge. Wang et al. [104] reported a method to manipulate the s-band of Zn by constructing B, N co-coordinated Zn-B/N-C catalysts (Fig. 5 a and b). Experiment results demonstrated that the two B-Zn-N pathways and the unique 3d 104s 1 property of Zn+ were the keys to enhancing activity and maintaining stability. Among them, Zn+(3d 104s 1) can accommodate enough delocalized electrons to generate suitable binding strengths for key reaction intermediates and facilitate charge transfer between the catalytic surface and ORR reactants (Fig. 5c and d). As a result, the resulting catalyst exhibited impressive ORR activity and remarkable long-term stability under acidic and alkaline conditions. Luo et al. [105] synthesized Zn-anchored 3D porous N-doped carbon framework (NDCF(Zn)-H2). Due to a large number of isolated Zn atomic adsorption sites, NDCF(Zn)-H2 exhibited high 4e− selectivity (n > 3.83) and excellent electrocatalytic performance for ORR. In alkaline electrolyte, its E 1/2 (0.88 V) was 33 mV higher than that of Pt/C. In addition, the NDCF(Zn)-H2 catalyst showed excellent stability, with only 18 mV of degradation in E 1/2 after 8000 accelerated stability tests. The results show that the main active center of the catalyst is pyridine N, and Zn can prevent the loss of pyridine N. Li et al. [106] successfully synthesized ultra-highly loaded Zn SACs (9.33 wt%) with Zn-N4 coordination. In acidic and alkaline conditions, the Zn SACs exhibited comparable ORR activity and stability to Fe-N-C catalyst. 2.2.7 Mo SACs Du et al. [107] prepared Mo SA/cluster catalysts (N-Mo-holey G) on N-doped 3D nanoporous graphene. The N-Mo-holey G catalysts can be used as efficient ORR and OER bifunctional electrocatalysts. N-Mo-holey G was used in solid-state Zn-air battery, which was flexible and could discharge/charge continuously for 88 h with a power density of up to 83 mW cm−2. Wang et al. [108] synthesized Mo SACs anchored by O-N bi-component center-coordinated Mo atoms (Mo-O/N-C). Mo-O/N-C catalyst exhibited excellent ORR catalytic performance under alkaline conditions (Fig. 5e), and the power density of the Mo-O/N-C-based Zn-air battery was 189 mW cm−2 (Fig. 5f). DFT calculations showed that the coordination of Mo with O and N atoms could shift its d-band center down, thereby optimizing its binding ability with reaction intermediates (O*, OH*, and OOH*), thereby accelerating the entire ORR process. 2.2.8 W Sacs Chen et al. [38] reported SW-N-C SACs with controllable coordination configuration for electrocatalytic ORR. It was found that the SW-N-C catalyst with WN5 coordination exhibited excellent ORR catalytic activity in 0.1 M KOH, with E onset of 1.01 V, E 1/2 of 0.88 V, and MA of 0.63 A mg−1 at 0.9 V. In addition, the E onset and E 1/2 of WN5 catalyst in 0.1 M HClO4 was 0.87 and 0.77 V. DFT calculations showed that the optimal dz 2 -pz orbital hybridization was due to the moderate interaction between OH− and W SAs, resulting in a lower barrier for the rate-limiting step of OH* desorption, which in turn made the ORR activity significantly increased. This work provides a research idea for the synthesis of pentagonal SACs. 2.2.9 V Sacs Cheng et al. [41] mimicked the structure of biological enzymes and constructed V-based SACs with N, O coordination in carbon matrix (V-N1O4) using glycine as a chelator. The V-N1O4 catalyst exhibited good ORR performance under alkaline conditions with an E 1/2 of 0.865 V, and as a cathode electrode for Zn-air batteries, its power density could reach 180 mW cm−2. DFT calculations showed that the N and O coordination structures could tune the electronic structure and geometry of V, in which the V-N1O4 structure exhibited significantly enhanced electron transfer, high electrical conductivity, and catalytic activity. This work not only proves that V SACs can be used in ORR, but also proves that O coordination SACs can improve catalytic performance, and provides a method for the development of high-performance ORR catalysts by adjusting the coordination environment. 2.2.10 Cr SACs Luo et al. [39] used ZIF-8 as the precursor to construct Cr SACs for the first time. The atomically dispersed Cr-N4 coordination structure was confirmed by EXAFS (Fig. 5g). The Cr SACs catalyst exhibited remarkable ORR activity under acidic conditions with an E 1/2 of 0.773 V (Fig. 5h). The catalytic activity of Cr SACs on Fenton reaction was obviously lower than that of Fe/N/C, so its stability was better than that of Fe/N/C, with only a 15 mV loss in E 1/2 after 20000 cycles (Fig. 5i). This work provides a research idea for solving the stability problem of traditional non-precious metal catalysts. 2.2.11 Ce SACs Like Fe, Ce has a significant redox coupling (Ce3+/Ce4+), which can promote O2 adsorption and thus enhance ORR activity. Ce has emerged as one of the most attractive rare earth metals due to the unique interconversion between Ce(III) and Ce(IV) oxidation states. Li et al. [42] synthesized a novel Ce-N-C electrocatalyst anchored on N-doped porous carbon nanowires (SACe-N/PC) with a Ce content as high as 8.55 wt%. SACe-N/PC exhibited excellent ORR performance under both acidic and alkaline conditions, with E 1/2 of 0.75 and 0.88 V, respectively (Fig. 5j and k). Furthermore, the SACe-N/PC-based Zn-air battery exhibited remarkable catalytic activity and stability. DFT calculations suggested that atomically dispersed Ce and adsorbed OH could promote ORR by lowering the energy barrier for the rate-controlling step (*OH desorption) (Fig. 5l). It can be seen from the above that researchers have done a lot of research on transition metal-based non-noble metal SACs, which also show ideal catalytic performance. The main group metals are generally not considered to have high catalytic performance due to their delocalized s/p energy bands. The following will introduce a small amount of research on the use of main group elements for electrocatalytic ORR. The research results show that main group metals also show potential in electrocatalytic ORR. 2.2.12 Mg SACs Due to the strong combination of Mg active center and oxygen-containing intermediates, the catalytic activity of Mg to ORR is hindered, while the N-coordinated Mg atom can adjust the binding strength with the intermediate oxygen group by adjusting the position of the p-band center. Bisen et al. [40] anchored Mg SAs on N-doped mesoporous carbon. The Mg-N-C catalyst exhibited superior ORR activity and stability. The modification of carbon nanostructures by N atoms could increase the O2 binding energy at Mg sites, thereby enhancing ORR activity. In addition, the poisoning study showed that the Mg-N x active center played a decisive role in ORR. This work opens up new strategies for the rational design and engineering of alkaline-earth metal-based catalysts. Liu et al. [109] investigated Mg SACs using DFT simulations and experimental studies. The results showed that the p-band center of Mg shifted upward and the adsorption strength of oxygenated species decreased, which was opposite to the trend of d-band metals (Fig. 5m and n). The catalytic activity of Mg could be tuned by coordinating with two N atoms, which originates from the modulation of p-band filling and then affects the ORR activity. The Mg SACs exhibited high ORR activity under alkaline conditions with an E 1/2 of 0.91 V. This work provides a research idea for designing highly active s/p band metal-based electrocatalysts. 2.2.13 Sn SACs Liu et al. [43] synthesized Sn-N-C SACs embedded in a mesoporous carbon support, and the Sn1-N-C exhibited the best ORR activity (E 1/2 of 0.87 V), 4e− selectivity and excellent durability. In practical applications, the Sn1-N-C based Zn-air battery had an output performance of 161 mW cm−2 at 250 mA cm−2. Sn SAs had an electroreduction effect on O2 molecules, and played a role in the pre-2e− process. In addition, Sn SAs had the ability to efficiently catalyze the reduction of H2O2, so Sn SAs catalyzed the entire ORR process via 2 + 2e− pathway. Various characterization data indicate that Sn SAs and N-doping species are active species to promote the ORR process. In addition, high degree of carbon defect, large BET surface area, and small impedance are also important reasons for improving the ORR activity. 2.2.14 Sb SACs Wang et al. [44] combined experiments and DFT calculations to synthesize Sb SAC with SbN4 site. The SbN4 sites along with the hierarchical porous carbon structure guaranteed abundant active site exposure and efficient mass transfer, resulting in extraordinary ORR performance with E 1/2 of 0.86 V. The Sb SAC exhibited an excellent power density of 184.6 mW cm−2 and a high specific capacity of 803.5 mAh g−1 in Zn-air battery. DFT calculations showed that SbN4 could activate the p electrons of Sb atoms, promote the charge transfer and p orbital interaction between Sb atoms and O2 molecules, and regulate the rate control step. 2.3 Non-metal SACs Se is a chalcogenide element with similar chemical properties to S, which is expected to have potential catalytic activity for ORR. It is also the only non-metallic SACs reported for electrocatalytic ORR at present. Hu et al. [45] successfully synthesized Se SACs anchored on NCs by a stepwise pyrolytic reduction method. Selenium dioxide was reduced to Se by NC at high temperature and partially fixed to form C-Se-C bonds. Se@NC-1000 exhibited a high E 1/2 of 0.85 V and a high current density of 5.53 mA cm−2, which was comparable to Pt/C. Furthermore, the Se@NC-1000-based Zn-air battery showed long-term durability and high discharge power density. This work laid the foundation for the development of non-metal SACs for ORR. 3 Precise structural regulation methods for improving ORR activity For SACs, the ORR activity can be improved by increasing the density of active sites. The intrinsic activity of the catalyst can be further improved by precise adjustment the structure of SACs, for example, by using interactions between metal atoms and supports, heteroatoms, and even other metal atoms [110–113]. Several regulatory approaches to improve the activity of SACs for ORR are described in detail below. 3.1 Coordination environment regulation Coordination environment regulation of SACs mainly includes two methods, one is coordination atom number regulation, on the premise of not changing the active center, changing the number of coordination atoms will have a great impact on the performance of electrocatalytic ORR. The second is coordination atom species regulation which can effectively regulate the intrinsic activity of metal active centers. Under the guidance of DFT calculation, Chen et al. [114] synthesized Co1-N3PS/HC SACs. Co1-N3PS/HC showed excellent ORR performance under alkaline condition with E 1/2 of 0.920 V. DFT results showed that the synergistic action of N, P, and S atoms induced the optimal electron density of atom-dispersed Co, which played an important role in improving ORR performance. Ma et al. [115] proposed an ion-exchange strategy to prepare Cu-N-C SACs (Fig. 6 a). The active center of Cu SAs/NC-900 catalyst was Cu-N3 coordination. The ORR performance of Cu-N-C SACs with Cu-N3 coordination was better than that of Cu-N-C SACs with Cu-N4 coordination (Fig. 6b and c), and its TOF value was 10 times that of Cu-N-C SACs with Cu-N4 coordination. DFT calculation further indicated that the low N coordination number was conducive to the formation of O2* intermediates, thus promoting the ORR process. 3.2 Electronic structure regulation By adjusting the electronic structure of the metal single atomic center, the most suitable adsorption energy can be obtained between the active center and the oxygen-containing intermediate, which is more conducive to the ORR process. Han et al. [116] confirmed that the adjacent Pt-N4 could assist the activation of O2 molecules at Fe-N4 site, and optimized the adsorption of intermediates by regulating the 3d electron orbital at Fe-N4 site, thus optimizing the ORR activity (E 1/2 = 0.93 V). Yang et al. [117] prepared Mn SACs with coordination of O and N atoms. Mn/C-NO catalyst had remarkable ORR performance. DFT calculation results showed that Mn-N3O1 active sites exhibited the fastest ORR dynamics, and its coordination O and N atoms could adjust the d electronic structure of Mn to the most reasonable state. Thus, the Mn atoms had the most suitable electron interaction with oxygen-containing intermediates (Fig. 6d–f). Mun et al. [118] introduced electron-absorbing/electron-donating groups on the carbon substrate through S doping to regulate the ORR activity of Fe-N4 active center (Fig. 6g). The experimental and DFT results manifested that the oxidized sulfur functionality could change the electron effect intensity of Fe atoms in Fe-N4, reduce the d-band center of Fe, and thus reduce the intermediate adsorption energy. 3.3 Support structure regulation The support structure has a great influence on electrocatalytic performance. If the support contains a large number of disordered micropores, not only the mass transfer resistance is large, but also a large number of metal active sites anchored in the micropores are difficult to contact the reactants, which leads to the reduction of atomic utilization and catalytic efficiency. Therefore, it is very important to design and use a suitable carrier to improve electrocatalytic performance. Han et al. [67] prepared ordered mesoporous carbon-supported Fe-N-C/N-OMC catalysts using ordered mesoporous silica (KIT-6) as a hard template. Fe-N-C/N-OMC catalyst had excellent catalytic activity (E 1/2 = 0.93 V), stability and methanol tolerance for ORR. The ordered mesoporous carbon support provided a high electrochemically active surface area, thus exposing enough FeN4 active sites. Secondly, an ordered mesoporous structure could reduce steric resistance and mass transfer resistance, to improve the accessibility and utilization efficiency of active sites. In addition, the pore wall could block the flow of Fe atoms and inhibit the agglomeration of Fe atoms, thus increasing the load of Fe-N-C SACs (2.9 wt%). 3.4 Heteroatomic doping regulation The modification of different electronegative heteroatoms can regulate the adsorption/desorption energy between the active site and the intermediate, and thus affecting the catalytic performance. On the one hand, the doping of heteroatoms can change the electronic structure of metal atoms and play a co-catalytic effect. On the other hand, the introduction of heteroatoms can coordinate with the metal center as a second active site affecting the electrocatalytic performance. Li et al. [119] used a simple copolymerization pyrolysis method to anchor Fe single atoms on S, N-co-modified porous carbon (Fe-ISA/SNC) (Fig. 6h–j). Fe-ISA/SNC with the N/S ratio of 1:1 showed significantly improved activity and stability. After 50,000 stability tests, the LSV curve almost did not shift. DFT calculation indicated that the lower electronegativity of S could increase the charge on N atoms and promote the reduction of OH*, thus speeding up the ORR process. Chen et al. [120] proposed a new MOF@polymer strategy to prepare Fe-SAs/NPS-HC catalysts. In alkaline medium, E 1/2 was 0.912 V, J k reached 71.9 mV cm−2 at 0.85 V (Fig. 6l and m). Importantly, Fe-SAs/NPS-HC demonstrated excellent performance in Zn-air battery and H2-air cell. DFT calculation revealed that the electron effect of S and P atoms reduced the positive charge of Fe, thus weakening the binding energy of adsorbed OH and improving the ORR efficiency (Fig. 6k). 3.5 Construction of double (multiple) atomic sites For ORR, the adsorption mode of O2 depends largely on the configuration of the active site. An ideal ORR catalyst should contain active sites conducive to the adsorption of O2 moleculars. O2 is more likely to adsorb on the double (multiple) atoms active site in a bridge mode, and its O = O bond is more likely to break. In addition, due to the regulation of the electronic environment and the synergistic effect of the second metal, double (multiple) atomic site catalysts have higher activity. Han et al. [121] synthesized Co-Ni dual site catalyst embedded in N-doped hollow carbon nanocubes (CoNi-SAs/NC) (Fig. 7 a). The Co-Ni diatomic structure was confirmed by AC-HAADF-STEM and XAS. CoNi-SAs/NC catalysts had excellent catalytic activity and long-term durability in dual-function ORR/OER and rechargeable Zn-air battery. DFT results confirmed that the synergistic effect of uniformly dispersed SAs and adjacent Co-Ni bimetallic centers could reduce the total barrier of ORR progress. Xiao et al. [122] proposed a novel OH ligand self-binding strategy to synthesize a Fe-Co diatomic center catalyst. Combined with the characterization and DFT calculation, the active center was FeCoN5-OH. It had excellent ORR performance in acidic medium, with ultra-high E onset (1.02 V) and E 1/2 (0.86 V). The stable anchoring effect of OH on FeCoN5 site leads to the optimal e g orbital energy level and ideal O = O bridge adsorption mode. The positive shift of the redox potential of Fe(III)/Fe(II) at the new active site was verified by DFT calculations (Fig. 7b and c) and operando XAS. Wang et al. [33] developed a host-guest strategy to construct Fe-Co double site catalyst anchored on N-doped porous carbon ((Fe,Co)/N-C) (Fig. 7d and e). Under acidic conditions, (Fe,Co)/N-C exhibited excellent ORR activity with E onset of 1.06 V and E 1/2 of 0.863 V (Fig. 7f). H2/O2 and H2/air fuel cell tests showed that the (Fe,Co)/N-C catalyst had cycle stability of 50000 electrode measurements (Fig. 7g) and long-term stability of 100 h. DFT calculation indicated that the double site was beneficial to the activation of O = O and promoted the 4e− ORR. 3.6 Construction of coupled catalytic sites The presence of nanoparticles in the coupled catalyst has two main effects. First, clusters/nanoparticles may change the electronic structure of the SASs to some extent to play a co-catalytic effect. Second, clusters/nanoparticles can act as the second active center to synergistically catalyze ORR process with SAs. Fu et al. [123] synthesized a novel 3D netted CoO X /Co-N-C(800) composite catalyst, in which CoO X nanoparticles were embedded on N-doped carbon (Fig. 7h–k). CoO X /Co-N-C(800) catalyst showed better electrochemical ORR activity and stability than Co-N-C catalyst. The excellent ORR performance of CoO X /Co-N-C(800) catalyst was due to the synergistic interaction between CoO X nanoparticles and Co-N-C SAs, as well as its structural advantages. Xiang et al. [125] prepared Pt/C-N catalysts with high activity and low Pt load. The results showed that highly dispersed Pt nanoparticles, Pt SAs, and pyridine N active sites were simultaneously formed in the high-temperature reduction process. Pt/C-N catalyst exhibited high ORR activity in 0.1 M HClO4, with an E 1/2 of 0.836 V. The high ORR activity was mainly owing to the synergistic catalysis of Pt nanocrystals, Pt SAs, and pyridine N atoms. Amiinu et al. [32] vertically grew layered MoS2 nanosheet arrays on N-doped carbon nano-frames, thus forming Mo-N/C centers on the interface (Mo-N/C@MoS2). Mo-N/C@MoS2 demonstrated remarkable multifunctional electrocatalytic activity and stability for ORR. Benefitting from the synergistic effect of the exposed edge of MoS2 nanosheets as the active center, the interface Mo-N coupling center, and the N-induced active center on adjacent carbon atoms in the N/C frame, the catalytic activity Mo-N/C@MoS2 was improved. 3.7 Spin state regulation The transition of spin states causes a series of physical and chemical changes. By regulating the interaction with coordination atoms, the spin state of the active metal center can be effectively regulated, thus improving its electrocatalytic ORR intrinsic activity. Cheng et al. [124] designed a surface non-pyrolytic strategy to synthesize Fe-N-C SACs. The FeN4 structure was determined by AC-HAADF-STEM, XAS, and 57Fe Mössbauer spectroscopy. Vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM) and electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra indicated that the defect carbon enhanced the high spin state of the Fe center in FePc (Fig. 7l and m), thus improving the ORR performance. The E 1/2 of FePc@N, P-DC in alkaline medium was 0.903 V (Fig. 7n), and after 10,000 cycles, the E 1/2 hardly changes. The flexible rechargeable Zn-air battery also showed outstanding performance. By introducing Ti3C2T x MXene as a carrier, Li et al. [126] improved the activity of the original Fe-N-C catalyst. The experimental results illustrated that the interaction of FeN4 group and Ti3C2T x MXene could cause significant 3d electron delocalization and spin-state transition of Fe(II) ion. The low local electron density and high spin state of Fe(II) center were favorable for electron transfer of Fe d z 2 , which makes the FeN4 site easier to adsorb and reduce oxygen, thus enhancing ORR activity. These results suggest that reasonable regulation of the spin states of metal active species is of great significance for enhancing the ORR activity of SACs, but it is still challenging. 4 Precise structural regulation methods for improving ORR stability Stability is also an indicator of high-performance ORR catalysts in harsh operating environments. Improving the stability of catalysts remains a major challenge in the development of ORR catalysts. The construction of ORR catalysts with high stability through efficient structural regulation methods will be the focus of research. Several strategies for improving SACs stability are described below. 4.1 Construction of coupled catalytic sites The presence of nanoparticles can be used as the second active center to rapidly transform H2O2 intermediates for further reduction, to reduce or even avoid the toxicity of H2O2 to the catalyst. In addition, nanoparticles can improve the stability of catalysts by adjusting the microenvironment of single atomic sites. Gao et al. [127] loaded Pt onto α-Fe2O3, and constructed a highly active and stable catalyst (Pt1-Fe/Fe2O3(012)) with dispersed Pt-Fe pair sites with E onset and E 1/2 of 1.15 and 1.05 V (Fig. 8 a), respectively, and MA of 14.9 A mgPt −1 at 0.95 V (Fig. 8b). Pt1-Fe/Fe2O3(012) catalyst had high stability after 50,000 cycles. The high stability was due to the synergistic effect of Pt-Fe sites, the Pt-Fe double sites could co-adsorb O2 and dissociate the O = O bond, while the OH* intermediate can be desorbed at the Pt sites. Cheng et al. [128] synthesized a high-performance Co-N-C nanofiber electrocatalyst (Co@SACo-N-C-10) with Co nanoparticles embedded in atomically dispersed Co and N-codoped carbon shells. Co@SACo-N-C-10 catalysts exhibited excellent ORR activity and durability in both acidic and alkaline media. In addition, Co@SACo-N-C-10-based PEMFC exhibited good performance (Fig. 8c). The results of experiments and DFT calculation (Fig. 8d) showed that the ORR performance was improved due to the core–shell structure, that is, the embedment of Co nanoparticles reduced the d-band center of Co active center on the surface of carbon shell, and thus enhanced the ORR stability. 4.2 Improve the four-electron ORR performance of SACs ORR involves a complex multi-electron transfer process, O2 can be reduced to H2O by a 4e− process (alkaline: O2 + 2H2O + 4e− → 4OH−, acid: O2 + 4H+ + 4e− → 2H2O) or to H2O2 by a 2e− process (alkaline: O2 + H2O + 2e−→ HO2 −+ OH−, acid: O2 + 2H+ + 2e− → H2O2). The peroxide generated in the 2e− ORR process can be further converted to H2O by another 2e− process (alkaline: HO2 − + H2O + 2e− → 3OH−, acid: H2O2 + 2H+ + 2e− → 2H2O). 4e− ORR and 2e− ORR are two competitive reactions that strongly depend on the type of O2 adsorption. There are three adsorption modes of O2 on catalyst surface, namely Griffiths mode, Pauling mode, and Yeager mode. Griffiths mode and Yeager mode are more conducive to O2 directly occurring 4e− ORR process, while Pauling mode is easier to follow 2e− ORR process. The 4e− process of direct dissociation of the O = O bond requires a dissociation energy of up to 494 KJ mol−1, while the 2e− pathway requires only 146 KJ mol−1 to produce H2O2 or HO2 −. 4e− ORR electrocatalysis provides a promising method for energy transfer and storage. However, 2e− ORR is inevitable during the reaction process, leading to the formation of H2O2 species, which reduces ORR stability. Therefore, it is an important strategy to improve the stability of catalysts by designing catalysts reasonably to promote 4e− ORR process. Because SACs have the unique isolated adsorption active sites, the ORR reaction path can be adjusted by rational design of the coordination environment of metal center. Qi et al. [129] theoretically studied the ORR mechanism, catalytic activity, and stability of CoN4 active center after S replaces the C atom around CoN4 active center (Fig. 8e). The results showed that S doping could improve the stability of CoN4-G, and CoN4S2-G had the highest stability. When the S atom was adjacent to the active center of CoN4, the ORR activity of the active center on the dented side was higher than that on the raised side. Dented side of CoN4S1-G had the largest E onset of 0.65 V. The thermodynamic driving force for the reduction of OOH to O*(or 2OH*) on S-doped catalyst was larger than that for the generation of H2O2, indicating that 4e− pathway was more favorable than 2e− pathway (Fig. 8f). Jia et al. [130] could achieve directional regulation of ORR pathway at atom-dispersed Zn sites by adjusting the coordination environment of the active center (Fig. 8g). Zn SACs with unique ZnO3C or ZnN4 coordination structures could be prepared by changing the functional groups of the MOF precursor. Among them, the ZnN4 catalyst generated H2O through 4e− ORR pathway in 0.1 M KOH, while ZnO3C catalyst had good activity and high selectivity to 2e− ORR. DFT results showed that O atom was more electronegative than N atom, the band center of Zn in ZnO3C moved to a lower energy direction (Fig. 8h). Therefore, by regulating the coordination environment of Zn atoms, the adsorption strength of Zn SACs on ORR intermediates changes, showing different selectivity and tending to different reaction pathways. 4.3 Improve methanol resistance of SACs Liu et al. [48] reported a low load Pt SACs (Pt1-N/BP) with high CO/methanol resistance supported by carbon black. Pt1-N/BP catalyst showed excellent electrocatalytic 4e− ORR activity, and the power density of Pt1-N/BP-based fuel cell reached 680 mW cm−2 at 80 °C and low load (0.09 mgPt cm−2). DFT calculation showed that the strong tolerance to CO/methanol was due to single atomic Pt active center anchored by the monopyridine-nitrogen atom. 5 Methods to reveal the structural evolution of SACs during ORR During the electrocatalytic reaction, the structure of the catalytic active site may change, and these structural changes are likely to affect the catalytic activity and stability. However, it is difficult to reveal the real active site and reaction mechanism of the electrode materials by ex-situ characterization technology. Therefore, utilizing advanced in-situ characterization techniques to monitor the dynamic changes of catalytic active sites during the reaction will facilitate the development of SACs. 5.1 In-situ Raman In-situ Raman can be used to observe the microstructure of catalyst and adsorbed intermediates on catalyst surface during the electrochemical reaction. It provides direct spectral evidence for observing intermediate species such as O2 −, OH*, and OOH* in ORR processes. Zhong et al. [131] developed PcCu-O8-Co SACs. Unpaired electrons in the σ* antibonding orbital (e g = 1) of the Co node lead to the formation of the Co-O4 center. PcCu-O8-Co/carbon exhibited excellent ORR activity in alkaline medium. The Co-O4 center and its interaction with intermediate during ORR were detected by in-situ Raman spectroscopy, and the Co-O was verified as the catalytic active site (Fig. 9 a and b). Li et al. [132] synthesized N-coordinated Fe SACs (Fe-NC-S), and demonstrated the structure and electronic evolution of active Fe SAs through in-situ Raman and operando XAS to capture *O2 and *OH intermediates under reaction conditions. In in-situ Raman spectrum of Fe-NC-S, a Raman peak appeared at 1083 cm−1 under 0.9 V, which was attributed to O-O (*O2 −) adsorbed on the active site. At 0.7 V, the peak intensity further increased. But no peak was observed at 1083 cm−1 in the in-situ Raman spectrum of NC-S. Combined with operando 57Fe Mössbauer spectra, the formation of O2 − intermediates was confirmed. 5.2 In-situ ATR-SEIRAS In-situ attenuated total reflectance surface-enhanced infrared absorption spectroscopy (ATR-SEIRAS) has obvious advantages in studying the microstructure and reaction mechanism of materials. In-situ ATR-SEIRAS can provide very rich molecular information and is commonly used to identify adsorbed intermediates in electrocatalytic reactions and to track their changes with time in kinetic studies. In-situ ATR-SEIRAS has become one of the necessary techniques to study reaction mechanisms. Tang et al. [133] changed the ORR selectivity from 4e− to 2e− on Co-SACs by modifying the first and second coordination layers. In-situ ATR-SEIRAS results confirmed that the *OOH was adsorbed at the Co atom center of CoNC and the adjacent C atom of O in CoNOC, but the adsorption of *OOH on the C atom was weak (Fig. 9e and f). The actual active site is transferred from the Co atom in the center to the C atom adjacent to the O atom in the second coordination layer, thus enhancing the 2e− ORR (Fig. 9d). The Co-SACs showed remarkable activity, high selectivity of 95%, and long-term stability of 11 h. Shang et al. [134] developed hierarchically porous carbon-based Cu SACs (S-Cu-ISA/SNC). Due to the rational construction of active sites, the S-Cu-ISA/SNC showed excellent ORR activity and good stability in alkaline medium, with an E 1/2 of 0.918 V. The results of operando XAS and in-situ ATR-SEIRAS indicated that the excellent ORR activity was due to the formation of the asymmetric Cu-S1N3 interface in the carbon substrate, and the low-valence Cu (+1) species was the active site of ORR. 5.3 Operando XAS XAS is one of the most powerful tools for detecting the local spatial and electronic structures of catalytic active centers, enabling in-situ detection of solid, liquid, and gaseous samples in a practical catalytic environment. Operando XAS based on synchrotron radiation source has high time resolution and can be used to study the reaction mechanism in the electrocatalytic reaction process. Shang et al. [135] constructed Mn SACs anchored on S and N modified carbon carriers (MnSAs/S-NC) using an atomic interface strategy. The stable Mn-N4-C x S y structure was confirmed by XAS. MnSAs/S-NC showed excellent ORR performance in alkaline medium with an E 1/2 of 0.916 V. Operando XAS results showed that the ORR activity of MnSAs/S-NC was increased during ORR process due to the isolated bond-length extending the low-valence Mn-N4-C x S y moiety. And the synergistic effect between Mn SAs and S, N co-modified carbon support resulted in excellent ORR activity (Fig. 9g–j). Han et al. [102] demonstrated the dynamic behavior of CuN2C2 site in ORR, linking the structural changes of SACs with their catalytic performance, and demonstrating the enhanced activity of CuN2C2 SACs under substrate induction. Operando XAS and DFT results showed that the CuN2C2 active site was geometrically distorted in response to the new coordination O-containing substance during ORR process, while the active site on the highly curved carbon nanotube substrate is more severely distorted to release strain. Therefore, the CuN2C2 active site on a reasonable carbon nanotube substrate exhibited optimal geometric distortion, with most of the electrons transferred to the adsorbed O2 molecule, resulting in a significant increase in ORR activity. 5.4 In-situ TEM As a real-time and high spatial resolution observation tool, in-situ transmission electron microscopy (TEM) can collect the structure and chemical information of electrode materials at the nanometer or even atomic scale, which is a powerful means to improve the monitoring of electrochemical processes, analyze the mechanism and study the structure–activity relationship. Wang et al. [136] synthesized Fe SACs with a special structure, which was isolated into an N-doped graphene nanonet and coated with a hollow carbon nanoshell (Fe-NGM/C-Fe). The formation mechanism of the Fe-NGM/C-Fe structure was observed by in-situ TEM. The results indicated that Fe-based nanocrystals contribute to the formation of graphene nanonets, and Fe SAs can be anchored in the graphene nanonets. Fe-NGM/C-Fe showed excellent ORR performance, higher current density, and stronger methanol poisoning resistance than Pt/C. The results confirmed that the electrocatalytic active site is the Fe-N site in the carbon matrix. 6 Summary and prospect In this paper, we systematically review the application of SACs in electrocatalytic ORR. Several important structural precision regulation methods for improving the activity and stability of ORR are introduced, including coordination environment, electronic structure, heteroatomic doping, and construction of double (multiple) atomic active sites and others. In addition, in-situ characterization techniques such as in-situ Raman, in-situ ATR-SEIRAS, operando XAS, and in-situ TEM for studying the catalytic active center and reaction mechanism of SACs during electrocatalysis are discussed. Although SACs have achieved surprising results in electrocatalytic ORR, there are still some challenges to be addressed in this field. (1) To prepare SACs with high loading and high performance for ORR, it is necessary to develop a green synthesis method with the advantages of simple, efficient, and large-scale production. (2) Although SACs have shown better electrocatalytic ORR activity than commercial Pt/C, the stability of SACs still remains challenging to meet industrial standards. Therefore, exploring efficient structural control methods to design and synthesize ORR catalysts with high stability will be the focus of future research. (3) The active center of SACs and their change in ORR process are still difficult to explain clearly. Advanced in-situ characterization techniques combined with DFT calculation can provide insight into the real active site and catalytic reaction mechanism of SACs. (4) To facilitate the 4e− ORR process and improve selectivity, an efficient double (multiple) atom site catalyst can be constructed to make O2 more likely to adsorb on the active center in bridge mode, and the O = O bond is more easily broken, thereby promoting the 4e− ORR process. Mater. 29 (2017) 9915-9922. Minmin Wang obtained her Master’s degree at China University of Petroleum (East China) in 2021. She is currently a Ph.D. candidate under the supervision of Professor Yunqi Liu and Yuan Pan at China University of Petroleum (East China). Her current research focuses on the preparation of single-atom catalyst and its application in electrocatalytic reaction. Hui Zhang obtained her bachelor’s degree at China University of Petroleum (East China) in 2022. She is currently a Master candidate under the supervision of Professor Yuan Pan at China University of Petroleum (East China). Her current research focuses on the preparation of single-atom catalyst and its application in electrocatalytic oxygen reduction reaction. Yunqi Liu is a professor in State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing at China University of Petroleum (East China). He was awarded a Ph.D. in Applied Chemistry from China University of Petroleum in 2000. Dr. Liu then worked two years as a postdoctoral follow in Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics at Chinese Academy of Sciences. His research interests focus on petroleum refining and chemical engineering, catalytic materials and catalysts. Yuan Pan received his Ph.D. in College of Chemical Engineering at China University of Petroleum (East China) in 2016. After postdoctoral work at Tsinghua University with Prof. Yadong Li, he joined the College of Chemical Engineering at China University of Petroleum (East China) as an associate professor in 2019. His research interests focus on the design and synthesis of single-atom materials for energy-related catalytic application.

coredata.dc:description: The development and utilization of renewable clean energy can effectively solve the two major problems of energy and environment. As an efficient power generation device that converts hydrogen energy into electric energy, fuel cell has attracted more and more attention. For fuel cells, the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) at the cathode is the core reaction, and the design and development of high-performance ORR catalysts remain quite challenging. Since the microenvironment of the active center of single atom catalysts (SACs) has an important influence on its catalytic performance, it has been a research focus to improve the ORR activity and stability of electrocatalysts by adjusting the structure of the active center through reasonable structural regulation methods. In this review, we reviewed the preparation and structure–activity relationship of SACs for ORR. Then, the structural precision regulation methods for improving the activity and stability of ORR electrocatalysts are discussed. And the advanced in-situ characterization techniques for revealing the changes of active sites in the electrocatalytic ORR process are summarized. Finally, the challenges and future design directions of SACs for ORR are discussed. This work will provide important reference value for the design and synthesis of SACs with high activity and stability for ORR.
